title: How many confirmed cases of COVID-19 will have been reported by the World Health Organization (WHO) for the Americas Region as of 1 February 2021?
preds: With the current case count at 45.3M and about 26 hours left, the chances of another 600K+ cases being reported is nonexistent given that the daily reporting rates have hovered around 315K.

The Americas region currently has 45,345,051 cases as of 2021-01-31. Daily new cases for the Americas region in last 14 days: mean=286,826, median=290,032. Assuming a constant rate of daily new cases (at 14-day mean value) gives a projected total of 45,631,877 on 2/01/21. Final answer.
It is still tight, but three days over 300,000 per day are extremely unlikely with current trends
Updating forecast based on latest WHO data, the remaining time for this question, and comments from other forecasters.

Unlikely that a massive reporting spike or discovery of a miscount in cases would bridge the gap between the current count (44.77M) and 46M.  The chance is still significantly non-zero, torn between 1 and 2% as 1 in 50 and 1 in 100 are radically different and I'd love a 1.5% here. I've conservatively settled on 1% - it is pretty unlikely
Probability of crossing 46M decreasing further given ~3 days to go and current case count at 44.7M (so +1.3M required)

The Americas region currently has 44,765,625 cases as of 2021-01-29. Daily new cases for the Americas region in last 14 days: mean=301,216, median=299,450. Assuming a constant rate of daily new cases (at 14 day mean value) gives a projected total of 45,669,274.
Doubling rate is increasing in the Americas. Increasing confidence of 44M - 46M bracket further
Typo!  I put 100% in the wrong category.

As of 24 January, WHO is reporting 43,456,972 cases.
- -Over the past week, there was 2,127,479 new cases. - To get to the 46 million threshold that differentiates the two most likely bins, there will need to be 2,543,028 cases in the next week.
- In the past 9 weeks, there has only been one week that approached that total (2,522,297), with zero surpassing the necessary number.  With straight math on historical activity, there is is a 0% chance we can get there, while there is a 11% chance we might approach that number. With just one week left on this question, I'm going all-in on being less than 46 million

Cases are trending downward. It is unlikely to surpass 46 M. The Americas region currently has 44,471,901 cases as of 2021-01-28. Daily new cases for the Americas region in last 14 days: mean=306,028, median=315,780 Assuming a constant rate of daily new cases (at 14-day mean value) gives a projected total of 45,696,012.

Today: 44,471,901
Daily new cases during the last 2 days: 220,000-274,000 If 220,000 during 4 days or if 274,000 during 4 days => <46,000,000

Would require more than 400k new cases a day to pass the 46M mark, which has been reached in the past, but now that the trend seems to be lower than it used to, it's very unlikely that the number of cases will jump that fast.

Unless there is a huge spike in the next 5 reports, this is very unlikely to get above 46M. As of 1/27 - 44,197,482 - rolling average of .65% increase puts this total at 45,660,000 (rounded). The daily rate would need to average .803% over the next 5 days to hit 46M. The rate has been declining even with day to day variances.

The current case count is 44.2M with 5 days left.  The cases thus far this week have averaged 250K new cases in the Americas each day.  If the next 5 days stay on the same trajectory, there would be about 45.5M cases in the Americas on February 1st.
Cases would need to average >500,000/day to reach 46,000,000

The Americas region currently has 44,197,482 cases as of 2021-01-27. Daily new cases for the Americas region in last 14 days: mean=311,589, median=324,903. Assuming a constant rate of daily new cases (at 14-day mean value) gives a projected total of 45,755,426.
Needs ~350,000 per day from now. Keeping to 4% for now as the exact numbers over the next couple of days will be extremely important.

Analysis:
I'd been relying on OurWorldInData as my data source as the Americas charts weren't showing up for me on the WHO link last time I checked. According to the WHO numbers now, we're at ~44M as of Jan 26th. This is lower than the 44.3M as of Jan 25th, that I'm seeing on OurWorldInData. Revising the calculations below, we'd need a doubling rate of <=13 weeks to see the total case count cross 46M[1] Result:
- Update probability of 44M - 46M significantly to the most probable interval
- Lower 46M-48M estimate significantly Reference:
[1]: https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=43.985*e%5E%28%28ln%282%29%2F13%29*6%2F7%29

Analysis:
- We have seen a increase in total cases of +4M in 2 weeks from January 11th (my last estimate) to January 25th[1]
- We have 1 week remaining and rate of increase is dropping in the Americas
- To stay below 46M, with case count=44.3M on Jan 25th[1], we'd need the doubling rate to drop to 18.4 weeks[2]
- To cross 48M, we'd need the doubling rate to increase to 8.6 weeks[3]
- If we maintain our previous assumption of a doubling rate of 11 weeks, we expect to see 47.8M total cases
- If we update our previous assumption and slow the doubling rate to 15 weeks, we expect to see 46.39M total cases by Feb 1st Updates:
- Make the peak probability between the 46M - 48M with a significant probability increase in the next lower bracket. Drop the probability for the >48M significantly. References:
[1]: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..2021-01-26&country=NorthAmerica~SouthAmerica&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=total&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
[2]: https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=ln%282%29%2Fln%2846%2F44.3%29
[3]: https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=ln%282%29%2Fln%2848%2F44.3%29
Time for me to recognize the higher daily counts I’d anticipated are not coming in time to push the total above 46M by Feb 1.

43.8 million now, 2m+ for the last 3 weeks. trending down though with new Brazil varient could see a return to growth
45.8 as median case with +/- 20% error bars...

With 6 days remaining, flat case counts would result in a final tally of 45.7M. Barring a surge in counts this week, this question should resolve just under the 46M count threshold. I'll increase the chances on the 44-46M range each day unless such a surge appears in the data.

The Americas region currently has 43,843,324 cases as of 2021-01-26.
Daily new cases for the Americas region in last 14 days: mean=306,422.0, median=324,903.0
Assuming a constant rate of daily new cases (at 14 day mean value) gives a projected total of 45,681,859.0 Time to update @cafebedouin

today:43,843,324 Daily new cases during the last 5 days: 288,000-334,000 If 288,000 during 6 days: 45,571,324
If 406,000 during 6 days: 46,279,324

There are 43.76M confirmed cases in the Americas with 7 days left.   In order for cases to reach the 46M mark about 2.24M more cases would need to be reported in the next week.  There have only been two weeks in the history of the pandemic, where case numbers have surpassed 2.24M.  And those weeks were around the holiday timeframe.   The United States' numbers make-up about half of the coronavirus numbers for the Americas.  These numbers have been trending downward and appear to continue to do so.  
https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2021/01/23/coronavirus-christmas-surge/
With the downward trend and no major American holidays coming up, I am increasingly confident that the number of cases will fall ~400,000-700,000 short of 46,000,000.

Percentage increase is trending down and the rolling 7 day average is .70% If this % holds, it would be about 45,949,000 cases. 
If it trends further down (85% of current average) it will be about 45,615,800 cases I see day to day variance, but overall a declining trend

The Americas region currently has 43,763,906 cases as of 2021-01-25. Daily new cases for the Americas region in last 14 days: mean=322,878.0, median=324,903.0 Assuming a constant rate of daily new cases (at 14 day mean value) gives a projected total of 46,024,051.5
Think it's going to end up around 45,500,000 million.
Still need 2,236,094 cases to reach 46,000,000. The weekly graph for the Americas currently seems to show a decreasing trend, and last week was 2,127,479 cases. Still hedging my bets a bit, though.
Slowing down too much for us to get into bin 4, but it will be close.
8 days on average below 317875 to stay in bin 3. This will be really close. Staying at 50:50.

As of 24 Jan 2021, WHO reported 43,456,972 in the Americas Region.  Weekly data from 11 Jan through 24 Jan roughly followed the trend forecast below with increases from 4 though 11 January and a return to the four week average thereafter.  In order to exceed 46,000,000 by 1 February, the America's region would have to report 2,543,028 new cases this week, which would be the largest number of cases reported in a single week since the start of the pandemic.

Regressing to the mean overall. Based on the forecasting models below, I think the total will end up just above 46 M. Though, I would be pleasantly surprised if I were wrong and there were fewer cases. The Americas region currently has 43,456,972 cases as of 2021-01-24. Daily new cases for the Americas region in last 30 days measures: mean=319153.0, median=324903.0. Assuming no growth or decline with a constant rate of daily new cases (at the 30-day mean value) gives a projected total of 46010192.8. A forecast through 1-31-2021 using logistic growth assuming a country-specific cap at the 99th percentile of past new daily cases gives: 4.91e+07 (lower:4.50e+07, upper:6.27e+07). A forecast through 1-31-2021 using linear growth in FBProphet gives: 5.23e+07 (lower:4.66e+07, upper:6.99e+07).

The Americas region currently has 43,133,022 cases as of 2021-01-23. Daily new cases for the Americas region in last 30 days: mean=319265.0, median=326596.0. Assuming a constant rate of daily new cases (based on the mean for the last 30 days) gives a projected total of 46,006,411.  A different forecast using a logistic growth assuming a country-specific cap at the 99th percentile of past new daily cases gives: 4.89e+07 (lower:4.49e+07, upper:6.26e+07).

I really, really want to jump on the <46M bandwagon, but I’m just not feeling it in my heart yet. This virus has gotten the better of the Americas region for a little over 365 days, and no amount of confidence in our abilities to reign it in will change that fact. Vaccinations are coming, but more slowly than expected. Behavioral change in this region is light years behind that of Asia and Europe. A slight breeze could shift the momentum enough to take us over 46M in a little over a week. I’ll be delighted if I’m wrong about this.
Looks as if it could come down to what time of day the data is recorded at.

50/50 now
At tjhe moment, it seems unpredictable between 44m-46m and 46m-48m.
Average increase 01/16-01/23: 315,782
If the daily increase from 01/24 > 318,553 it will be > 46m cases

Sitting at ~350K new cases per day for the month so far. Continuing that forward puts us quite close to 46M cases - the question is whether the worst of the month is behind us or ahead of us. If we've seen the peak of spread due to the holidays *and* broad redoubled efforts to limit spreading are effective then we should end up under 46M, but close. If case rates increase then we'll end up north of 46M. I am feeling unusually optimistic (for me) and think that we have seen the worst of case rates in January for the Americas. While I did increase [46M - 48M], I suspect we're more likely to see <46M. I'll check in again on monday when my optimism will likely have faded and see if i still agree.

42.8m now and 200k cases per day gives over 9 days about bang on 44m.  To get to 46m it’s 355k cases per day. It’s going to be close, but am plunging for the more likely to pass to bin 3 than not.  Bin 4 looks too far off.

Overall, I am regressing to the mean. The daily new cases seem to be stable or slightly decreasing. The Americas region currently has 42,807,169 cases as of 2021-01-22. A forecast through 1-31-2021 using linear growth in FBProphet gives: 5.24e+07 (lower:4.66e+07, upper:6.98e+07). A forecast through 1-31-2021 using logistic growth assuming a country-specific cap at the 99th percentile of past new daily cases gives: 4.88e+07 (lower:4.48e+07, upper:6.23e+07).

As of 17 January 202, the WHO Weekly epidemiological update states there are 41,329,493 cases in the Americas. - Over the past week, there were 2,467,817 new cases.
- In the previous week, there were 2,522,297 new cases. 
- The week prior was 1,935,621 new cases. Using the most recent week's statistics for the next two weeks would be 4,935,634 over the last two weeks of the month.  That would bring the final total to 46,265,127.   In order to drop down below 46 million, the next two weeks would have to average a drop of 132,563.  That is a fairly minuscule difference, so I need to add more weight to the 44-46 million category, which I'll pull from the more than 48 million. Comparing my forecast to the crowd, I'm still below the average, but I think the data is too close to 46 million to warrant dropping below 30% at this time.

Today: 42,473,014 Daily new cases during the last 5 days: 288,000-406,000 If 288,000 during 10 days: 45,353,000
If 406,000 during 10 days: 46,533,000

Average # of cases/day in next 11 days to reach 44,000,000: 138,816.909
Average # of cases/day in next 11 days to reach 46,000,000: 320,635.091
Average # of cases/day in next 11 days to reach 48,000,000: 502,453.273
Average # of cases/day in next in the last week (starting on the 13th): 375,834.714
Average # of cases/day in the week before that (from Jan 6th): 372,522.286 Seems like cases/day are staying relatively stable, and are on track to get us in the 44,000,000-46,000,000 range. Although it's possible the new variant could up things somewhat, it likely won't become the dominant variant until March (https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2021/01/13/956504515/u-k-variant-could-drive-a-new-surge-in-the-u-s-experts-warn), so won't have a big effect until after the question closes. Biden's mask mandate (https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/airline-news/2021/01/21/president-biden-issues-federal-mask-mandate-on-flights/4214019001/) could help things too, but because of lag the effects of that probably won't be felt until about a week after the mandate went into effect. It is also doubtful how this could be enforced.

On current estimates, the total should come in just under 46,000,000. However the last 7 days of results have all been less than the reported figure from 7 days prior to that. The signs of a reducting in cases is there. Don't want to go too low on the over 6 million probability however. The USA is bonkers and who knows what socialising might have been occuring around a rather controversial Inauguration.

The Americas region currently has 42,473,014 cases as of 2021-01-21. A forecast through 1-31-2021 using linear growth in FBProphet gives: 5.24e+07 (lower:4.66e+07, upper:6.99e+07). A forecast through 1-31-2021 using logistic growth assuming a country-specific cap at the 99th percentile of past new daily cases gives: 4.88e+07 (lower:4.46e+07, upper:6.22e+07).

The Americas region currently has 42,184,253 cases as of 2021-01-20. A forecast through 1-31-2021 using linear growth in FBProphet gives: 5.20e+07 (lower:4.62e+07, upper:6.93e+07). A forecast through 1-31-2021 using logistic growth assuming a country-specific cap at the 99th percentile of past new daily cases gives: 4.86e+07 (lower:4.43e+07, upper:6.19e+07).
My extremely rough estimate for this is just shy of 47M.  It is probably wrong.

If case counts hold flat, the 46M mark is very close to the projection. In effect, a decline over the next 10 days will result is the third options while any increase will land us in the penultimate. It would take a dramatic surge (or data dump) to cross 48M from here). As the data are lumpy, I'm not swinging fully down without a couple of confirmation days.

To exceed 48 million they would have to average 3.6 million cases per week. Currently the last two weeks are around 2.5 million per week. To stay below 46 million there would have to be less than 2.46 million cases per week. Looks like it's on the cusp of 46 million and could fall either way, but cases in the US are trending down and US cases drive the trend for the region for the most part.

The Americas region currently has 41,776,035 cases as of 2021-01-19. A forecast through 1-31-2021 using linear growth in FBProphet gives: 5.23e+07 (lower:4.64e+07, upper:7.07e+07). A forecast through 1-31-2021 using logistic growth assuming a country-specific cap at the 99th percentile of new daily cases gives: 4.86e+07 (lower:4.44e+07, upper:6.29e+07). The logistic model assumes countries have reached saturating growth, which is set at the 99th percentile of max daily new cases.

Going all in on Bin 4 because it looks like as long as there is an average of 308,633.7857 cases per day it will get there. The average for the last 11 days is 376,421.2727 cases per day. Bin 5 would need 451,490.9286 cases per day average to get past 48,000,000. Bin 3 would take between 165,776.6429 and >308,633.7857 cases per day.

There are currently 41.7M cases of COVID-19 in the Americas.  The rates have remained consistent around 2.5M for the last two weeks.  Since, there are two weeks remaining, 4.3M-6.3M new cases need to be reported to end up in the 46M-48M range.   The graphs for COVID-19 are exponential and thus do not function on strict averages.  Exponential averages weight the more recent data more.  Even with that, there would need to be more than 3.15M cases per week for the next two weeks to have more than 48M cases, which seems high given that we are almost three weeks after the New Year.   Low End:
to achieve 46M - 2.15M per week with average rates at 2.5M per week - highly likely High End:
to achieve 48M - 3.15M per week with average rates of 2.5M per week - highly unlikely

The Americas region currently has 41,680,773 cases as of 2021-01-18. A forecast through 1-31-2021 using linear growth in FBProphet gives: 5.24e+07 (lower:4.67e+07, upper:6.91e+07). A forecast through 1-31-2021 using logistic growth in FBProphet gives: 5.45e+07 (lower:4.64e+07, upper:7.51e+07). The logistic model basically assumes countries have reached saturating growth at some point during the pandemic (cap = max daily new cases). References:
https://covid19.who.int/table
https://pypi.org/project/fbprophet/

Today:41,329,493 Daily new cases during the last 2 weeks: 242,000-447,000 If 242,000/days during 2 weeks: 44,717,000
If 447,000/days during 2 weeks: 47,587,000

The Americas region currently has 41,329,493 cases as of 2021-01-17. A forecast through 1-31-2021 using linear growth in FBProphet gives: 5.24e+07 (lower:4.67e+07, upper:6.87e+07). A forecast through 1-31-2021 using logistic (saturating) growth with a country-specific growth cap on daily new cases set to the country maximum daily new cases gives: 5.44e+07 (lower:4.63e+07, upper:7.49e+07).  This logistic model basically assumes countries have reached saturating growth at some point during the pandemic (cap = max daily new cases). References:
https://covid19.who.int/table
https://pypi.org/project/fbprophet/
more contagious virus mutations in UK, South Africa and Brazil spreading around the world
Thanks for the head's up @LikeAFox, I forgot I had even forecasted this one.
Adjusting due to the new variant becoming more prevalent in the States

The Americas region currently has 40,922,526 cases as of 2021-01-16. A forecast through 1-31-2021 using linear growth in FBProphet gives: 5.23e+07 (lower:4.66e+07, upper:6.87e+07). A forecast through 1-31-2021 using logistic growth in FBProphet gives: 5.43e+07 (lower:4.61e+07, upper:7.48e+07). 
@cafebedouin
The WHO is continuing to report daily tallys of approximately 350,000 throughout the Americas.  That puts the tally square in the 46-48 million range.

The Americas region currently has 40,548,449 cases as of 2021-01-15.  A forecast through 1-31-2021 using linear growth in FBProphet gives: 5.23e+07 (lower:4.65e+07, upper:6.86e+07). A forecast through 1-31-2021 using logistic (saturating) growth in FBProphet gives: 5.42e+07 (lower: 4.61e+07, upper: 7.45e+07). References:
https://covid19.who.int/table
worried that the new strain could make the numbers worse than expected

Average daily growth rate Jan 1 - Jan 13 is 0.9074%
Below 42m requires average growth to be 0.279% for the rest of the period
Below 44m requires average growth to be 0.525%
Below 46m requires average growth to be 0.760%
Below 48m requires average growth to be 0.986%

On the low side, fewer than 42M cases would require an average of 127,340 cases/day for the next 17 days. The 1/14 number was 281,800. This implies a decay rate of 10% per day. While not impossible, that seems unlikely.  On the other end, getting over 48M requires an average of 480,282 cases/day. Any exponential growth rate greater than 6% per day would achieve that. As of right now, cases are in decay rather than growth. Vaccinations and mitigation efforts should help control that. If the trend is flat (or decay) from here, the number will be less than 48M by the end of the month.  Holding the line flat from here is 44.6M. So, the second option implies decay in case rate for the rest of the month.

As of 1/14 (40,187,505). With a recent average of +/-360,000 cases per day, we will comfortably pass the 44M mark. (18 days x 360k = 6.48M additional cases = 46,667,000). Many of the states from the Rt Live question are starting to trend back under 1.00. Even if the average cases per day drops to say +/-300k that is 5.4M new cases = which is 45,587,000. Alternatively, if you take the recent daily increase rate and use a +/-15% range and add to the current case count of 40,187,505 the result is the following range: 46,652,000 to 49,160,000 (rounded).

The total cases for the Americas region (as of 2021-01-14) is 40,187,505. The majority of cases are from the United States with 22,645,757 cases (56.40% of total). A forecast through 1-31-2021 using logistic (saturating) growth in FBProphet gives: 5.21e+07 (4.52e+07, 7.04e+07).

Just under 40m as of today.  New cases running between 200k and 400k over last week or so.  18 days left.  So at 20lk per day this is an additional 3.6m.  At 400k per day this is 7.2m.
Weighting slight more from bin 5 to 3.  Keep bin 4 same.

Shifting back after some additional research and the news that the new variant of COVID from the UK is now in many states. I think the drop we have seen is temporary, and it will go back up. We have not seen the results from the spread related to the gatherings at the Capital and the ones expected in the next few weeks either.  Bin 2: 113,974.05 cases or more per day average (42,000,000-39,835,210=2,165,507) (2,165,507/19=113,974.05)
Bin 3: 219,237.21 cases or more per day average (44,000,000-39,835,210=4,165,507) (4,165,507/19=219,237.21)
Bin 4: 324,500.368 cases or more per day average (46,000,000-39,835,210=6,165,507) (6,165,507/19=324,500.368)
Bin 5: 429,763.526 cases or more per day average (48,000,000-39,835,210=8,165,507) (8,165,507/19=429,763.526)

Seeing some significantly reduced numbers in the U.S., so now I am unsure we can get to bin 5. I know the WHO is a bit short on numbers for the last few days, since the U.S. has had about 20,000 more cases than the WHO recorded, but it seems to be slowing in the U.S. so I am hedging my bet. Here are the new numbers as of today.  Bin 2: 113,974.05 cases or more per day average (42,000,000-39,835,210=2,165,507) (2,165,507/19=113,974.05) 
Bin 3: 219,237.21 cases or more per day average (44,000,000-39,835,210=4,165,507) (4,165,507/19=219,237.21) 
Bin 4: 324,500.368 cases or more per day average (46,000,000-39,835,210=6,165,507) (6,165,507/19=324,500.368) 
Bin 5: 429,763.526 cases or more per day average (48,000,000-39,835,210=8,165,507) (8,165,507/19=429,763.526)  The 6 day average is 371,738.8 cases per day, but since the U.S. has been seeing less of a case load, the last three days have been below 300,000 cases per day, with yesterday being 281,800. I still believe that there will be an additional 20,000 cases from yesterday in the U.S., but it still puts it in the bin 3-4 range for now.
Adjusting due to new COVID variant spreading in US (https://www.newscientist.com/article/2264672-warnings-of-huge-new-spike-in-us-covid-19-cases-as-uk-variant-spreads/ ).

Assuming we're just now reaching the peak of new cases from the holidays and new years (i know, it is a grand assumption but we're at 2 weeks after NYE which I hope was the last country-wide super-spreader event in the US for the season).  Optimistically, I assumed an average of 300k new cases per day on average from now until the end of the month as the lower end which puts us comfortably over 44M.  Pessimistically, I assumed 400k per day from now until the end of the month as the upper end which puts us comfortably under 48M.  Because of the nature of how the virus spreads, people's fatigue with mitigation strategies (masks, distancing, etc) and how difficult it is to reduce the rate of infection (the US in particular isn't doing great with the shared responsibility of reducing the infection rate) - I see it 3.5x more likely that we significantly overshoot the range I identified than to undershoot it, giving us 2% (a 1 in 50 chance) for 42M-44M and a 7% (a 1 in ~14 chance) for >48M
Adjusting due to the new COVID variant spreading in the US

The total cases for the Americas region (as of 2021-01-13) is 39,835,210. The majority of cases are from the United States with 22,428,591 cases (56.30% of total). My rough estimate is for the number of cases to fall in the range 45 M to 52 M.

The total cases for the Americas region (as of 2021-01-13) is 39,552,693. The majority of cases are from the United States with 22,229,803 cases (56.20% of total). Unfortunately, the US continues to have over 200k cases per day. If the US continues these rates, my projections are that the US alone could increase 4 million from 22 M to 26 M. Given the current status of 39.5 M, an additional 4 M from the US would bring the total for the Americas region to at least 43.5 M assuming no new cases in any other country in the region. References:
https://covid19.who.int/table
https://covidtracking.com/data
https://covid19.healthdata.org/global?view=resource-use&tab=trend&resource=all_resources

Right after my previous post, the WHO COVID-19 Weekly Epidemiological Update was published, which reported 2,522,297 new cases over the past week for a cumulative total of 38,861,668 on 10 January. Taking 2,522,297 and multiplying it by three weeks gives 7,566,891, or a total of 46,428,559 by 31 January.   *Note*
10 January - 31 January is three weeks, but the question states "as of 1 February", which according to how the WHO is reporting, would include 1 February.  Therefore, there are actually 22 days of counting between 10 January and 01 February.  However, this question closes on 01 Feb at 3:00am PST, which means it closes at 2400 on 31 Jan EST.  Therefore, the 1 Feb data will not be included.

COVID-19 Situation in the Region of the Americas for January 11th, 2021 15:00 (EST):
- An additional 309,078 cases and 3,856 deaths were reported in the past 24 hours

Adjusting previous forecast due to definitive increase from the holidays. Weekly cases grew from less than 2,000,000 cases per week the previous two weeks (December's last two weeks), to 2.5M cases the week of the 4th. Still don't see the case count breaking 48M yet, but will continue to monitor. From previous forecast: Based on the information provided by the WHO the Americas region is averaging about 2,000,000 cases per week +-200,000 cases for the last few weeks. I expect cases will remain in the weekly range of 1,800,000 to 2,100,000, so assuming that and adding these numbers for the next 4 weeks I get the following: 1,800,000 cases per week -1% 43,701,956
0% 44,143,389
+1% 44,584,822 2,000,000 cases per week -1% 44,493,956
0% 44,943,389

+1% 45,796,822 I included a range of +-1% for each estimate to capture edge cases, and considering the number of cases over the last couple months (per week) I fully expect more than 42,000,000 cases in the Americas by February. I don't believe the number of cases will exceed 46,000,000 cases by February, so as weekly case numbers come in I will adjust accordingly within the range of 42,000,000 and 46,000,000. Case numbers have been dropping the last two weeks, so it is possible cases could be below 44,000,000, but they would really need to come down each week to end up below that number.

Today: 39,552,693
My last prediction was too optimistic: in the last 12 days there has been no slowing of the epidemic; the effect of the vaccination and the season will take longer to show. If the number of cases remains around 2 million to 2 1/2 million per week :
- 45,500,000 cases if 2 million / week (optimistic scenario)
- 47,000,000 if 2.5 million per week. Some forecaster who have written a rational think that the number of cases may also be more than 48,000.

Process:
  1. Model the case growth as an exponential.
  2. Observe doubling rate of 11 weeks from 20M to 40M from October 27th - January 11th
  3. For reference we see a doubling rate of 12.3 weeks and 5.14 weeks for the case count doubling before that respectively
  4. Assuming doubling rate for next 3 months is at 10 weeks : 11 weeks : 12 weeks with odds 1 : 3 : 2
      That is, assuming most probable doubling rate is the current doubling rate with a tilt towards faster spread than slower spread, we get expected value of 48.02 Million cases by Feb 1st
   5. Spread the probability across all possible outcomes such that peak at >48M, a slight drop in next lower interval, and sharper drops for levels in subsequent lower intervals

References:
  - Data Source: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..2021-01-11&country=NorthAmerica~SouthAmerica&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=total&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
  - Exponentiation Doubling Rate: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doubling_time#Cell_culture_doubling_time   - https://www.paho.org/en/topics/coronavirus-infections/coronavirus-disease-covid-19-pandemic
    - Has data for Americas region based on WHO data. The OurWorldInData reference I've used for my estimates currently aren't based on WHO numbers
    - Has doubling rate graphs too. Use it to validate against my current manual doubling rate evaluations

The WHO's COVID-19 Situation in the Region of the Americas on January 10th, 2021: An additional 380,886 cases were reported in the past 24 hours.  Combining that with the previous day is a total of 825,027; or an average of 412,513.  Taking that over 7 days is 2.89 million per week; 11,550,364 for a 4 week run. Adding the 11,550,364 to the 3 January total from my original forecast (36,337,439) results in: 47,887,803.   It's looking less and less like 44-46 million, and more like 46 million-48 million (or more).   I'm adjusting my bins and purposely overcoming the anchoring bias of my original forecast.

The Americas region currently has 39,242,554 cases as of 2021-01-11. It is too early to be precise, but my rough estimates range from 44e6 to 52e6. 
https://covid19.who.int/table

To stay below 48 million the Americas would have to average below 2.25 million new cases per week. Below 48 million the average would have to be 2.92 million cases per week. The average over the last week was 2.52 million cases per week. Readjusting to make 46 to 48 a little more likely than the others and adding some likelihood to 48+. To get below 44 million there would have to be 1.6 million cases per week, which looks very unlikely at this point.

New numbers after the weekend, which had 825,032 new cases (441,146 and 380,886). Unfortunately, I believe this will still roll into bin 5. The weekends are generally slow for the U.S., and I expect it to pick back up today, but this also makes it hard to predict where the final numbers will fall. Also, with the super spreader event that took place in the Capital, in addition to several political rallies in other states, such as Georgia, I would expect to see some increase in numbers shortly as well. I think bins 1-3 are out based on U.S. numbers alone, and I will probably start leaving them off in the near future, but I am not entirely convinced that bin 4 is out and bin 5 is a sure thing. The week of 4 January saw a spike in COVID-19 cases with over 2.5M cases reported in that week alone.  There are currently 39.2M cases in the Americas.  Given the exponential growth of this disease and the expected post-holiday spike, experts anticipate these numbers will climb.  An average of 2.93M is needed for the next three weeks in order to reach a total of more than 48M.   Conservative Estimate (rates stay around current weekly rate):
39.2M + (2.5M*3 weeks) = 46.7M Increasing Estimate (rates increase from where they currently are):
39.2M + (3M * 3 weeks) = 48.2M

On 9 January, the WHO reported an additional 444,141 cases were reported over the past 24 hours.  Extrapolated over 7 days, that would be an increase of 3.1 million over a week.  That number would shatter previous week highs and is well above my estimated high based on the last 7 weeks of data.  I am adjusting my forecast to move towards the 46-48 million bin.

Average daily growth rate Dec 31 - Jan 10 is 0.82%. For it to stay below 42m the rate has to be below about .35%. 
For below 44m it's 0.59%
For below 46m it's 0.81%
For below 48m it's 1.01%

I took a relatively simple approach since I wasn't able to find weekly data in a CSV file quickly and could only find WHO data for the past week. Looking at the current WHO data, there are 38,861,668 cases in the Americas. The average of the weekly increase of each country in the Americas is 6.6% for the past week. Without data on how much a vaccine would potentially reduce cases of COVID, I applied a 6.6% increase weekly for the next 3 weeks and got around 47 million cases in the Americas. By comparing this against the weekly charts on the website, it looks like the Americas have experienced about a 2-2.5 million case increase weekly, over the next three weeks that would mean 6-8 million additional cases.

Looking at flu trends for the Americas for the past 4 years between weeks 1 and 5 presents an average of 61% increases in flu cases.   The vaccine is rolling out in North America (53% of the Americas population) although only to a limited, most at-risk portion of the populations thus far.  Therefore assuming around a 75% increase in cases reported from week 1 to week 5 of 2021.   The vaccine is only rolling out in Central and South America (47% of the population) in a very few countries and therefore I'm assuming a much higher increase of 90% in cases reported from week 1 to week 5 of 2021.   I've not seen any changes in reporting techniques in the Americas for the WHO website.  Taking into account the week 1 total for the Americas of 2,522,297 cases and multiplying by the aforementioned percentages weighted for population, I'm estimating a total of 43M cases on 01-Feb.   If I'm off, it's likely too low, and therefore I'm giving a high probability to 44-46M as well.

As of 2:50 PM, 10 Jan 2021, the WHO reported 38,861,668 COVID cases for the Americas Region.  This leaves 22 days through 1 February 2021 for this forecast.  For the last two months, the WHO reported an average of 1,987,695 new infections per week, or 283,956 per day.  Simply following this trend, total infections reported through 1 February would be 45,108,700. Mass gatherings associated with national-level celebrations appear to have a significant impact on weekly transmissivity rates.  The two weeks after Thanksgiving saw increases in new infections above the two-month average.  Weekly infections for 7 December rose by 2,054,064 and rates for the week of 14 December rose by 2,321,202, (greater than one standard deviation).  The explanation for the delayed increase following mass gatherings is COVID’s incubation and pre-symptomatic period.  COVID patients can remain pre-symptomatic between 2 and 14 days after infection, meaning reported infections don’t spike for up to two weeks following mass gatherings.  The week of 4 January (the first week of data after Christmas/New Year’s) already exhibits the same post-Thanksgiving trend, only on a larger scale (many more people in the Americas Region celebrate Christmas and New Year’s than Thanksgiving).  New cases for 4 January rose by 2,522,297 (almost two standard deviations).  Following this trend, we should expect new infections to rise again the week of 11 January, before returning to the two-month average.  Applying the same percentage increase from the “Thanksgiving bump” (7 to 14 December), we should expect new infections for the week of 11 January to rise 13% over the previous week.  This would put 11 January’s weekly infection rate at 2,850,195.  Adding this to the two-month weekly average for the remainder of the forecast period gives us 45,971,203 confirmed COVID cases by 1 February. Two other factors worth considering are public health restrictions and vaccinations.  A cursory review of State Department travel advisories shows several countries in the Americas Region implemented more stringent travel, social distancing, and gathering requirements on or about 17 December.  Since this was largely a response to the “Thanksgiving bump” I anticipate these measures will only restore new weekly infections to the two-month average and not further decrease infections in just 22 days. Vaccination will also have a negligible impact in the next 22 days.  Of all the countries in the Americas region, just the U.S., Canada, Mexico, Costa Rica, Chile and Argentina have started administering vaccines (the latter three countries have vaccinated less than 0.5% of their populations).  The U.S. currently vaccinates approximately 500,000 patients per day and the Centers for Disease Control states that it takes up to 28 days for a patient’s immune system to develop sufficient antibodies to prevent infection.  This should not significantly alter my forecast of 45,971,203 infections.   My confidence level of 67% is based on the standard deviation of the two-month weekly data (312,664).  67% of data samples should fall within one standard deviation of the mean.  Since 45.9 million is at the upper end of the designated range bracket (44M to 46M) one standard deviation above would push my forecast above this bracket.

I am pushing to 100% for more than 48m.
Between 06/01 and 10/01 number of cases increased for 1.91m (38861668-36943000=1918668), which give 479k per day. With 21 days left it gives us a little over 10m new cases (10073007). So we are a little over 48m.
As we can see a surge in new cases after Christmas holidays, I assume that this trend will keep upwards for week or two. Following decrease trend will start at the break of January and February.

As of January 10, 9:30am CET there were 38,861,668 confirmed cases in the Americas region according to the WHO.  New cases in the last seven days were 1,935,621 in the region. This represents an average weekly increase of 5.33%. Extrapolating that percentage increase over the next three weeks would get us to 44,724,905 cases by February 1.  Other factors to take into consideration are potential increase in spread, the effects of vaccine distribution, and potential reporting delays.  
I assume that there will still be a higher increase in the rate of infections coming out of the holiday period since symptoms can present themselves up to 14 days after infection. Because of these factors it is highly unlikely that cases will be below 44 million. The U.S. and Brazil had large weekly increases in the past week and Colombia, and Mexico also had modest increases. Expanding the outer limit to a 7% weekly increase puts us in the upper range right around 46,900,000. Therefore the most likely brackets are 44-46M and 46-48M.
Recent numbers look more like a question btw. 46-48m vs. 48m+

Forecast being done on 1/9. 23 days left to add to case counts. 
Outside view: According to the WHO dashboard, right now there are 40.76 million cases in the Americas. New cases reported in the last 24 hours is 441,576. The US has the preponderance, WHO reported 277195 yesterday. The CDC 7 day rolling average is 248K new cases in the US (country w/ largest impact on americas), with the trend continuing to spike. At 23 days times 441K cases, that’s an extra 10 million cases on Feb 1 after the Jan 31 cases are accounted for. That brings the total to 50.76 million. Even if the US amounts are not at a rate of 277K per day (CDC count is higher at 314K) and are instead at the 7 day rolling average, that only eliminates ~690K cases. 
Inside view: The vaccine rollout has been slow, effects are still happening from holiday travel, and the B1.1.7 mutation is just starting to get going in the USA. It is the beginning of winter and people are going to be indoors. No major changes in preventive measures. (Although there could possibly be after the inauguration, but best case that wouldn’t have an effect until past 1 Feb). The trend line gives me no reason to believe that the 7 day average will even level off, let alone subside. No major breakthroughs on the horizon. Based on these factors, my estimate is 97% confidence that the Americas total is above 48 million, 3% confidence that it’s between 46-48 mil. Update 1/25. It appears like the initial data set I pulled off the WHO website for 40.76 million cases in the Americas on 1/9 is different than the data now shown, of 38.4 million. The rate has also slowed. Currently it's at 43.8 million, with 7 days to go. For the week of Jan 18 there were 2.1 mil cases, and the trend is to go down. Updating my estimate to be 80% b/w 44-46 mil, 20% b/w 46-48 mil.

According to Our World in Data, the combined number for North + South America today is 39 million confirmed cases. Whereas North America is fluctuating quite wildly, the curve for South America appears more stable. Importantly, the more transmissible variant b.1.1.7 has only recently been confirmed in Colorado, California, Florida and New York. It is quite likely that the variant has reached both North/South America regions, given it was discovered in Kent/London as early as September. However, while it is likely to be present, the extent to which is contributing to spread is unclear. All other things equal, the inveitable introduction or continued spread of the more transmissible variant is likely to increase cases at a higher rate than what is currently seen. So what rate of confirmed cases are we currently seeing? In the past month, North America has seen an increase of approximately 400 confirmed cases/million people every day, i.e. approximately 230-235,000 cases per day. Compared to the 7th of December, this is an approximate doubling of the number of cases/day. With the introduction of the new variant, and taking into consideration Christmas and NYE, as wella as the slow rollout of vaccinations, I think it's reasonable another doubling in the month to come. While not a full month away, this would mean that on February 7th there would be approximately 460,000 new confirmed cases per day. On average, this means an additional 345,000 cases per day between now and February 1st. 24 days remain until the 1st of February. 345,000*24 = 8,280,000. For simplicity's sake,  For S America, the growth has been somewhat slower overall, but is showing a strong upwards trend currently. Assuming another doubling between now and and February 1st, this means an increase from the current 165 confirmed daily cases per million people, or 71,000, to 330 per million people, or 142,000. On average, this means 106,000 cases per day until then, or 2,544,000 cases.  39,000,000+8,280,000+2,544,000 = 49,824,000, which would put my prediction towards the very top of the question alternatives.  Going against this is the increasing immunization of people, either through exposure themselves or vaccination. Without vaccination data in South America, it is difficult to factor this in.

According to the WHO website's COVID-19 Weekly Epidemiological Update dated 3 January,  there are 36,337,439 cases in the Americas as of 3 January. There are 28 days, or four weeks, between 3 January and 1 February. The question boils down to identifying if the trend will continue (relatively) linear, or increase (steeper slope), or decrease (trend downwards). According to the Weekly Epidemiological Update (https://www.who.int/publications/m/item/weekly-epidemiological-update---5-january-2021), there were 1,935,621 new cases over the past week in the Americas.  If that straight trend continued, that would be 7,742,484 new cases in the next 4 weeks, meaning 44,079,923 cases on 1 February.  - The week of 3 January, the case rise was 1,935,621
- The week of 27 December, the case rise was 1,965,774
- The week of 20 December, the case rise was 2,321,202
- The week of 13 December. the case rise was  2,054,064
- 6 Dec: 1,845,816
- 29 Nov: 1,652,915
- 22 Nov: 1,603,498
- Going further back to 1 November for a sanity check: 999,652 new cases. Bottom line: Cases in the Americas are steady, or going up.   So the weekly change has a low boundary of 1.6 million and a high of 2.3 million over the past 6 weeks; that is a difference of 700,00 cases per week.  Extrapolated over 4 weeks, that could lead an error of 2.8 million if the lower number is used as opposed to the higher number.  That is definitely enough to move from one bin to another bin, so it is fairly important to get the upper and lower boundaries correct. - I don't believe the vaccine will play a major role in stemming the rise of cases.  There just is not enough people receiving the vaccine quickly enough to stem the rise. - However, Christmas gatherings could significantly increase the rate at which people spread the disease.  Christmas is a Christian holiday, which the vast majority of American nations practice Christianity.   - Let's assume an average of 2.5 million new infections per week over the next four weeks (a higher number than we've seen, but reasonable boundary).  That would be 10 million new cases, putting us just over 46 million confirmed cases.   - If there were 1.6 million new cases a week (lower boundary), that would be 6.4 million new cases, putting us at 43 million cases.  - 2 million cases a week seems like the sweet spot.  That is 8 million over the next 4 weeks, which puts us at 44,337,439. I don't see rates significantly slowing down.  I don't think there is enough to get us over 46 million either.  The sweet spot is 44-46 million.

I expect in the next 22 days that confirmed cases will average 300,000 per day.  Adding that amount (6.6 mil) to the current total (38 mil) equals an expected value on Feb 1 of 44.6 mil.  My forecast is centered on that amount.  I expect error to be on the higher case load side based on slow vaccine rollout and more contagious viral mutations recently.

Coming off of weekend and holiday low reporting periods, we have seen that the case numbers are steadily rising in the U.S. again. I do not expect this to slow down in the next few weeks since those that were exposed during the holidays will start getting sick right about now. With quarantine fatigue and the unlikely potential for shutdowns effecting the numbers for several weeks even if implemented today, I do not see this being anything less than the current weekly average of 306,443.571 cases per day. At this average, we would be in the 44,000,000-46,000,000 bin by 1 Feb (306,443.571*24=7,354,645.704+37,538,493=44,893,138.704). However, today’s numbers are probably more telling, as we have reached 348,951 cases and the reporting period is still not over. I can easily see the numbers in the U.S. getting up to around 270,000-300,000 cases a day on its own. The U.S. had 260,937 cases reported yesterday according to a source other than the WHO, who is a little bit slower at increasing numbers. However, the U.S. is at 227,369 today according to the WHO. The other site I used has a similar number for two days ago, at 234,711. I expect tomorrow’s WHO numbers for the U.S. will likely be somewhere between 240,000 and 260,000, and the total for the Americas will also likely go up significantly. There are always dips in the numbers over the weekends, so I expect that the average will stay somewhere in Bin 4 for now, but we will see as the next few days show us what is happening after the holiday family gatherings.  I didn’t calculate the first bin because I don’t think we will see numbers that low at all. I also believe that the U.S. will get the total for the Americas close to or into Bin 3 on its own, but I calculated bins 2-5 just to see what it looked like. Bin 5: 435,896.125 cases or more per day average (48,000,000-37,538,493=10,461,507) (10,461,507/24=435,896.125) These numbers will change daily, but I believe it is likely that we will see increasing numbers hopefully leaving us somewhere in the Bin 4 range and not Bin 5. However, I do believe the next two months will be the worst on record for the U.S., and this will likely put the total in Bin 4. After a few more days, when the averages change significantly I will reassess.
